thread.title_full: Female journalists paid 26 per cent less - survey

author: Madison Reidy
title: Female journalists paid 26 per cent less - survey
text:
Female journalists paid 26 per cent less - survey MADISON REIDY Last updated 16:11, February 28 2017 123RF 
Female journalists are less likely to be promoted than their mail counterparts. 
Female journalists are paid 26 per cent less than the male colleagues despite outnumbering them in newsrooms and being more likely to have a university qualification, a study shows. 
Researchers surveyed and interviewed 539 journalists aged mostly between 21- and 60-years-old in December 2015 to January 2016 for the the 2016 Worlds of Journalism Study, 
It found the average gross income of journalists was $69,400 in 2015. 
However, the average salary after-tax for women was more than $10,000 less than men in equally ranked journalism jobs. 
READ MORE: * Women still paid less than men around the board table - Institute of Directors fees report 
Women are also less likely to be promoted with half of male journalists working in management roles compared to a third of women.. 
Senior journalism lecturer at Auckland's University of Technology Helen Sissons said she's not surprised by the disappointing findings. 
"Females work hard, they should be paid equally," Sissons said. 
She said she was unsure what to say to the 70 per cent of her students that were female. 
"It's not giving the right message to young women considering journalism as a career." Ad Feedback 
Those surveyed also rated the changes happening in the industry. 
The study found that in the preceding two years journalists' working hours have lengthened and the shift to digital news platforms has added growing commercial pressures, weakening journalists' credibility and ethical standards. 
But the majority believed that social media, search engines and user-generated content have helped them. 
Head of journalism at Massey University Dr James Hollings​ who led the study, said: "It is concerning that journalists feel these changes have affected news quality, with a perception that the credibility of journalism, ethical standards and freedom to make editorial decisions have all fallen". 
"Another concern is that, despite evidence of some improvement, Maori, Pasifika, and Asian reporters remain under-represented in newsrooms. 
Maori make up only 7.9 per cent of the journalism workforce, despite making up 15 per cent of the general population, Hollings​ said. 
On the positive side, journalists are better educated than they have ever been, and overall adherence to ethical standards remains high, he said. 
Almost all respondents agreed with the statement 'Journalists should always adhere to codes of professional ethics, regardless of situation and context'. 
Job satisfaction also remains high. 
"It is clear that New Zealand journalists, despite these pressures, continue to take their role as guardians of democracy very seriously," Hollings​ said. - Stuff.co.nz
